Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
The purpose of this project is to fabricate low-dimensional interface structures that enable the creation of new types of matter and the observation of new nanoscale phenomena. Such phenomena include interactions between atoms, molecules, and nanocrystals in low-dimensional environments defined by the interfaces between 2D layers of graphene and boron nitride (BN). This program will employ newly developed techniques for manipulating single layers of graphene and BN in order to fabricate low dimensional interface structures and to characterize them using scanning tunneling microscopy and transmission electron microscopy techniques. Interface structures will be decorated with a combination of atoms, molecules, and nanocrystal elements deposited via vacuum deposition and solvent-based spin-coating techniques. These structures will allow the exploration of completely new transmembrane chemical bonding and tunable electromagnetic behavior at the nanoscale. Graduate students, undergraduates, and postdoctoral researchers will be engaged at every level of this research, and will obtain training in state-of-the-art nanofabrication and microscopy techniques. High school students will be offered internships in this program to promote recruitment into the sciences.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
This project is aimed at characterizing new types of microscopic structures made by trapping atoms and nanometer-sized particles between two-dimensional layers of graphene and boron nitride (BN). Because the graphene and BN layers can be made only one-atom-thick, particles on either side of these membranes will interact strongly with one another, thus changing their overall properties in ways that have not been previously observed. Particles trapped at the interfaces between such membranes will be visible to different types of high-resolution electron microscopy, allowing their detailed behavior to be measured. This will allow the creation of new types of two-dimensional materials whose properties can be tuned into useful regimes that have never before been accessible (including, for example, their optical, electronic, and magnetic behavior). Such materials are expected to be useful in future electronic devices and also for creating new surface coatings with highly desirable properties. Graduate students, undergraduates, and postdoctoral researchers will be engaged at every level of this research, and will obtain training in state-of-the-art nanostructure fabrication and microscopy techniques. High school students will be offered internships in this program to promote recruitment into the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

            Over the lifetime of this grant the PIs studied different 2D hierarchical interface systems using a variety of microscopy tools capable of imaging single atoms. The hierarchical nature of the 2D systems studied arises from the fact that they were stacked on top of each other, resulting in hierarchies consisting of a substrate, overlayer #1, overlayer #2, overlayer #3, etc., with atoms, molecules, and defects incorporated into the different layers and between them. The purpose of this research was to explore these different layered systems and to understand their fundamental properties. This has great intellectual merit because these 2D systems are brand-new materials that are not well understood and that have significant potential technological benefits. Because they are only one atom (or just a few atoms) thick, they are more responsive to their immediate environment than other more conventional bulk materials. The purpose of this research was to explore that responsiveness and to understand how new classes of 2D materials behave in different nanoscale environments.

            A significant amount of effort was put into exploring different layer stacking sequences of graphene and transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) materials. We determined the electronic structure of graphene bilayers (i.e., stacks of two graphene layers) placed on top of boron nitride (BN) in a field-effect transistor configuration (i.e., with a flat gate electrode underneath). We determined how graphene electronic properties change as the twist angle between graphene layers is modified. We also determined the electronic properties of single layers of semiconducting and metallic TMD materials on graphene. This included measuring their energy gaps as well as modulations in their charge density (“charge density waves”). We observed that charge density waves and superconductivity coexist even when TMD materials are thinned down to just a single atomic layer. We additionally determined how the energy gap of TMD semiconductors is modified as stacking sequences vary between one and three layers. We observed dramatic changes in electronic behavior with stacking sequence, and we explained these effects using modern theoretical tools to simulate the stacked layers.

            We also explored the consequences of combining 2D materials with atomic and nanoscale objects such as point defects, impurities, grain boundaries, and different types of molecules. We directly imaged how electrons in a single graphene layer rearrange themselves in the presence of a single charged atom. This is an important process called screening and our measurements were the first atomic-scale visualization of this process as a function of electron density in graphene. We also measured how graphene responds when hydrogen atoms stick to its surface, as well as molecules such as C60 and F4TCNQ. We also used graphene as a window to view defect behavior in insulators such as BN. Normally such defects can’t be imaged by tunneling microscopy in an insulator, but the presence of graphene gave us a new way to detect the defects by passing current through the graphene layer. This allowed us to develop new ways to use charged defects in insulators to confine electrons in graphene monolayers and bilayers placed above the insulators (i.e., to make quantum dots that exhibit novel quantum mechanical properties).

Broader Impacts:

            The broader impacts of this work were in the education and outreach activities that we performed. Most important was the training we performed for the next generation of scientists. This involved students at all levels, from high school students to college undergraduates to graduate students and postdocs. These students were trained in cutting-edge microscopy techniques such as scanning tunneling microscopy, atomic force microscopy, and transmission electron microscopy. Students were trained in how to fabricate nanodevices, and in how to characterize them using various techniques such as measurement of electrical conductivity. Students were trained in how to construct experiments to effectively test scientific hypotheses, in how to analyze data, and in how to write papers for high-impact scientific journals. Students were additionally trained in how to communicate their results in oral presentations to experts as well as to lay-people.

            Another important aspect of this project was the outreach that we performed to underrepresented minorities and to students who have experienced situations that adversely affect their advancement in science. In order to be most impactful we partnered with other institutional efforts such as the University of California’s Leadership Excellence through Advanced Degrees program (UC LEADS) and the Summer Math and Science Honors Academy (SMASH). The SMASH program was particularly effective in that it allowed us to partner high school students with graduate student mentors who introduced them to fundamental concepts used in research, and in how to navigate a laboratory in order to perform basic experiments.
